commit_message:
Fix euca exercise failing after upgrade.

Wait a few seconds after upgrading, so cinder-scheduler can receive
capabilities reported from cinder-volume.

Fix bug #1189595

Change-Id: I3c1394345327c09b6180d9031da9ea3a9f922a1e

commit_message:
Replace publisher name by URL

This allows to specify any amount of configuration option for each
publisher in each pipeline. UDP is the first to use this to possibly
publish to differents (host, port).

Blueprint: pipeline-publisher-url

Change-Id: I6a6f53ff438395c7bbbafad30efe097e1e01e1c6
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

[{'created': '2013-06-13 07:24:50.000000000', 'message': 'Use Python 3.x compatible octal literals

Python 3.x deprecated octal literals in the form
0755. Use 0o755  instead which works at least
with Python 2.6 and newer

Change-Id: I70dc33cb674499548732408924aa2ae728e17ea3
'}]
commit_message:
Use Python 3.x compatible octal literals

Python 3.x deprecated octal literals in the form
0755. Use 0o755  instead which works at least
with Python 2.6 and newer

Change-Id: I70dc33cb674499548732408924aa2ae728e17ea3

Fixes: bug #1190111

commit_message:
Stop passing path to VerifiedHTTPSConnection

This class doesn't expect this argument.  Passing the argument causes the
client to break on all HTTPS connections.

Change-Id: I56f02b3a8943ff9a8b9e7855796fd527683514f3
Fixes: bug #1190111

commit_message:
deploy element: Call find_disk in loop w/ timeout.

Updates our deploy element's init script so that it calls
find_disk in a loop until it returns true (meaning we have a disk).

Previously on some bare metal machines find_disk would return ""
which causes the subsequent iscsi target commands to fail due to
a bad backing store.

This commit also updates the error message when start_iscsi_target
fails to be a bit more accurate as well.

Fixes LP Bug #1190984.

Change-Id: I3cd535d6672c197c1c3c539c83bba36be7a14e18

commit_message:
Rename os-config-applier to os-apply-config.

This is being done to reduce confusion between os-refresh-config and
os-config-applier. In order to make the transition smooth, all this
patch does is rename the element, install the now pypi available
os-apply-config, and support both the old and new directory names
for templates, allowing incremental migration of users.

Change-Id: I8c4c7679799f4e8b436ce766791f45f4c81d75f2

'}]
commit_message:
Allows nova user to sudo without a tty.

Some distros have the requiretty enabled by default in the /etc/sudoers.
The nova user tries to run `sudo nova-rootwrap` without a tty causing
the command to fail.

Change-Id: I484652d16ff168b96ca9896669209a34043c4d57

commit_message:
Remove usage of locals() for formatting from cinder.volume.*

Using of locals() for formatting string is a nasty thing because:
1) It is not so clear as using explicit dicts
2) It could produce hidden errors during refactoring
3) Changing name of variable causes change in message
4) Creating a lot of unused variables

Fix bug 1171936

Change-Id: I806c530851527db9da251352be45b97c183241a8

setup_networks_on_host() method, results from
this call not used, no specific exception raised,
this patch just remove it.

Change-Id: Icf898dcdda635a3a78c92e76ec0e19c6ab075ce1

commit_message:
Remove unused db api call.

There is unused db api call in NetworkManager
setup_networks_on_host() method, results from
this call not used, no specific exception raised,
this patch just remove it.

Change-Id: Icf898dcdda635a3a78c92e76ec0e19c6ab075ce1

[{'created': '2013-06-14 23:39:36.000000000', 'message': "Remove the 'migrate' option from cinder-manage

The 'migrate' option was only appropriate for use migrating
databases for volumes from Nova-Folsom-->Cinder-Folsom.  The
code hasn't been tested since.

Given the above facts, this commit removes the migrate code from
cinder-manage.  The man page for cinder-manage was already
updated to remove the option in a previous commit.

(fixes bug #1187134)

Change-Id: I7bf378cd4b0dd4f6d1bdf475b826a59a31112638
"}]
commit_message:
Remove the 'migrate' option from cinder-manage

The 'migrate' option was only appropriate for use migrating
databases for volumes from Nova-Folsom-->Cinder-Folsom.  The
code hasn't been tested since.

Given the above facts, this commit removes the migrate code from
cinder-manage.  The man page for cinder-manage was already
updated to remove the option in a previous commit.

(fixes bug #1187134)

Change-Id: I7bf378cd4b0dd4f6d1bdf475b826a59a31112638

commit_message:
set default for gw conn info in nvp_networkgw extension

Bug 1183285

This patch simply guarantees default segmentation type and
id in gateway connection info for the 'connect' and 'disconnect'
actions are correctly set respectively to 'flat' and 0.

Change-Id: I1b4e8274651e05f4681878ab70daef990ece901b

commit_message:
Install agent packages when running agents like DHCP or L3

This is because these agents rely on quantum agent packages as
much as the L2 agent.

Fixes bug #1190050

Change-Id: I8b0c5667f86b22e3727a316f7bb0500d0d0ba637

[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-12 19:06:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/32761/1/check/gate-heat-pep8/3482 : SUCCESS in 1m 41s

- http://logs.openstack.org/32761/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/29947 : SUCCESS in 17m 36s
'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2013-06-12 23:40:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Shardy I am totally in favor of this, just a question about the naming of "state". I was expecting "action", state and status seem really similar - like someone reading/editing the code could get mixed up. Was there a reason for the change? Note I am not fixated on "action", it just makes it clear what the difference is.'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-06-13 07:17:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

@asalkeld: The reason was basically it seemed to fit in better with the current code and database naming etc.  However I'm perfectly happy to switch back to action if you prefer.

FWIW, my initial idea was to have lifecycle operations create/update/delete/rollback (which all change the stack definition), and transient "stack actions" suspend/resume/pause/restart/snapshot/etc (which do not).

This rename is going to end up lumping them all together due to the set_state usage, so I guess using action for all of them makes sense, but at the API level, I was trying to keep them separate (see stack actions API patch) maybe that is also a mistake, what are your thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 4328, 'date': '2013-06-13 10:25:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-13 11:09:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

commit_message:
Convert Events to separate action/status

First step in decoupling action/status in Resource

This adjusts the Event DB columns, model and class to split
action/status, but in order to be backwards compatible we set the action
to None, which means we can do the right thing in the CFN API, and
resource_status still maps correctly to what is expected in
python-heatclient (which will need to change after the Resource
action/status split happens)

Change-Id: I261d47d2a3fdb3cdc2a8aaf6c159763f4636f633

Do you want to know or do you want me to do it?'}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-06-16 06:55:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I am working on that :)
Basically one could do it as a part of the relevant plugin test case (in this case test_l3_plugin). But I think that would be wrong - the plugin test case is for testing the plugin, not for validating that policies are enforced on update/create router when external_gateway_info is passed.

If you think about it, that test will just verify that nobody changes RESOURCE_ATTRIBUTE_MAP for l3.py (so we might as well have just a case that checks that!)

So I am doing it as a part of test_policy.json.
The test would simply verify that for attributes with enforce_policy=False, the attribute is not added to the match_rule for policy validation; otherwise the rule for {create | update}_<resource>:<attribute> is added to the match list.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-16 06:55:32.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
Enable attribute-based policy on router:external_gateway_info

Bug 1186081

This patch also removes a check on is_write in policy.py since
the code block where that check is placed assumed already that
is_write == True

Change-Id: I21c54f63e1948675f67afb088c262dc5316c230d

commit_message:
Add datetime utils

Add iso2timestamp and timestamp2iso which could change format of
datetime into ISO 8601 or timestamp. Those will be useful for
x-delete-at header or modified time and so on.

Change-Id: I2df8a3d51a4155e935b69146ffd7407dc5512e68

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-11 16:10:46.000000000', 'message': 'Http 400 when project enabled is not a boolean

    Bug: 1189528
    Having enabled="true" in json data when creating tenant will produce 500

    When creating or updating a project, no type check was performed on the
    enabled attribute. Therefore, if enabled value in JSON/XML is not a
    boolean buta string or an int, keystone responds with an incorrect
    Http 500 error code and the stacktrace.

    The change introduces a type validation of the enabled attribute
    at backend and api layer. If the type is not a boolean, keystone
    now returns an appropriate Http 400 error code with a message
    pointing a bad format for the attribute.

    Test cases have been added to file test_backend and
    test_content_types for testing the case when enabled attribute is a
    string or int when creating or updating project.

    The same correction can be done for create/update domains.

Change-Id: Ic902824ba7d21bf09e5aebc8452c89c192d77ef3

commit_message:
Http 400 when project enabled is not a boolean

Having enabled="true" in json data when creating tenant will produce 500

When creating or updating a project, no type check was performed on the
enabled attribute. Therefore, if enabled value in JSON/XML is not a
boolean but a string or an int, keystone responds with an incorrect Http
500 error code and the stacktrace.

The change introduces a type validation of the enabled attribute at
backend and api layer. If the type is not a boolean, keystone now
returns an appropriate Http 400 error code with a message pointing a bad
format for the attribute.

Test cases have been added to file test_backend and test_content_types
for testing the case when enabled attribute is a string or int when
creating or updating project.

The same correction can be done for creating/updating domains.

Fixes bug #1189528

Change-Id: Ic902824ba7d21bf09e5aebc8452c89c192d77ef3

commit_message:
Remove class-based import in the code repo

Fixes bug 1167901

This commit also removes backslashes for line break.

Change-Id: Id26fdfd2af4862652d7270aec132d40662efeb96

commit_message:
Replace functions in utils with oslo.fileutils

The following functions have moved to oslo.
remove_path_on_error
file_open
delete_if_exists

Replaced/removed overlapping functions with the ones in fileutils

Change-Id: I41a19d76a777b6f899843bb0cc0582630accbd5c

commit_message:
Some libvirt driver lookups lacks proper exception handling

Add error handling to list_instance_uuids() and get_memory_mb_used().
While fixing list_instance_uuids, this change also removes an
unnecessary extra lookup for every running instance.

Improve test coverage for list_instances() and list_instance_uuids().

Change-Id: I0cabe5f38d19143a3eb7b2ebce1ea6ea63f36929

Use AuthRef for some client fields

This tackles some TODO items left over.

Change-Id: Ib062744acbf56f05d09857d244b78b35c0ef4d39
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

[{'created': '2013-06-12 15:13:43.000000000', 'message': 'Quantum API _get_floating_ip_by_address mismatch with Nova-Net

_get_floating_ip_by_address() has a unspecified behavior when
IP address is empty and only one floating IP is allocated in
the pool. It should return a 404 Not found like Nova-Net does
but instead returns the only IP in the pool.

Fix bug #1190242

Change-Id: Id4843edda8e66ccabab5e9d053c595a1cd247770
'}]
commit_message:
Quantum API _get_floating_ip_by_address mismatch with Nova-Net

_get_floating_ip_by_address() has a unspecified behavior when
IP address is empty and only one floating IP is allocated in
the pool. It should return a 404 Not found like Nova-Net does
but instead returns the only IP in the pool.

Fix bug #1190242

Change-Id: Id4843edda8e66ccabab5e9d053c595a1cd247770

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 1501, 'name': 'Phil Day', 'email': 'philip.day@hp.com', 'username': 'philip-day'}, {'_account_id': 1711, 'name': 'Yun Mao', 'email': 'yunmao@gmail.com', 'username': 'yunmao'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2750, 'name': 'Sean Dague', 'email': 'sean@dague.net', 'username': 'sdague'}, {'_account_id': 4690, 'name': 'melanie witt', 'display_name': 'melwitt', 'email': 'melwittt@gmail.com', 'username': 'melwitt'}, {'_account_id': 5652, 'name': 'David Ripton', 'email': 'dripton@redhat.com', 'username': 'dripton'}]

'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2013-06-09 07:39:05.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Shouldn't this change have https://review.openstack.org/#/c/32145 as a dependency? Otherwise if a reboot fails, another reboot can't be attempted to recover.

What if an active/running instance experiences an error during the reboot operation but is still running afterward? It would be switched to error state. Is that desired in this case?"}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2013-06-10 19:53:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I think the debatable issue is probably whether we want to go into Error state if reboot fails. I think in the new V3 API design, it's a "soft error" so vm_state doesn't need to be updated. But I couldn't find the design doc at the moment. I personally prefer to leave vm_state intact if reboot fails. This would be a non-issue either way once the other patch 32145 is merged.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-06-10 21:04:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Maybe we should make it dependent on the power state after the reboot then.  Consider this scenario (which came out of our testing) with the current code:

1) Delete the VM with virsh and remove all files for the VM:  Instance goes to Shutdown

2) Issue a reboot:   Reboot will fail and log an error, but the Instance will now show as Active

Seems like going to Error is better in this case, and from there it can be recovered via rebuild.

So how about we retain the previous state if reboot fails and the power_state shows it is running, but go to Error if not ?'}, {'account_id': 1711, 'date': '2013-06-10 21:06:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Phil: I think that's a good idea!"}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-06-12 16:12:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-07 23:38:24.000000000', 'message': 'Fix bad vm_state change in reboot_instance()

Currently reboot_instance() in the compute manager
changes the vm_state to active before it does anything
else. This means that if there is an error in the reboot
operation then the vm_state is left as active although
the instance may not be running.

This change leaves the vm_state alone until the reboot
has successfully completed, and also set vm_state to
error if the reboot fails.

See also https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1183946
which make recovery from an Error state possible.

Fixes bug: 1188343

Change-Id: Idabd358d3bcaf63e21ff59188f805143dbaf9ada
'}, {'created': '2013-06-14 19:32:45.000000000', 'message': 'Fix bad vm_state change in reboot_instance()

Currently reboot_instance() in the compute manager
changes the vm_state to active before it does anything
else. This means that if there is an error in the reboot
operation then the vm_state is left as active although
the instance may not be running.

This change leaves the vm_state alone until the reboot
has completed

If the reboot fails but the power_state shows that it
is running then we log the fault but leave it in an
active or rescued state

If the reboot fails and the power_state shows that it
is not running then we set vm_state to error

See also https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1183946
which make recovery from an Error state possible.

Fixes bug: 1188343

Change-Id: Idabd358d3bcaf63e21ff59188f805143dbaf9ada
'}]
commit_message:
Fix bad vm_state change in reboot_instance()

Currently reboot_instance() in the compute manager
changes the vm_state to active before it does anything
else. This means that if there is an error in the reboot
operation then the vm_state is left as active although
the instance may not be running.

This change leaves the vm_state alone until the reboot
has completed

If the reboot fails but the power_state shows that it
is running then we log the fault but leave it in an
active or rescued state

If the reboot fails and the power_state shows that it
is not running then we set vm_state to error

See also https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1183946
which make recovery from an Error state possible.

Fixes bug: 1188343

Change-Id: Idabd358d3bcaf63e21ff59188f805143dbaf9ada

commit_message:
Don't make nova-compute depend on iSCSI

Because not all volume drivers require iSCSI it makes sense to not
set the initiator in the connector and let the volume drivers
return an error if iSCSI is required.

bug #1007084

Change-Id: I5da472e5013fdc0c733ecb12b919c1068873bdc6

commit_message:
Refactors qemu image info parsing logic

The _parse method is using position information on a list
which is not intuitive. Removed position info and did a clean up
addressing python conventions.

Change-Id: I412d62f9f5a045773b65ed38230eddec48c91e1b

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-03 17:11:49.000000000', 'message': 'Fix to disallow server name with all blank spaces

* Nova CLI allows server name to be created with all blank characters.
  This fix will disallow a server name with all blank spaces during
  server/instance creation as well as while updating/renaming a server
* Adding unit tests to test the above scenarios (create & rename
  server with blank spaces)

Fixes bug 1175956

Change-Id: I58af207c4a6b8579bb172d4bb612e0aa2aa6b498
'}, {'created': '2013-05-03 19:11:51.000000000', 'message': 'Fix to disallow server name with all blank spaces

* Nova CLI allows server name to be created with all blank characters.
  This fix will disallow a server name with all blank spaces during
  server/instance creation as well as while updating/renaming a server
* Adding unit tests to test the above scenarios (create & rename

commit_message:
Fix to disallow server name with all blank spaces

* Nova CLI allows server name to be created with all blank characters.
  This fix will disallow a server name with all blank spaces during
  server/instance creation as well as while updating/renaming a server
* Adding unit tests to test the above scenarios (create & rename
  server with blank spaces)

Fixes bug 1175956

Change-Id: I58af207c4a6b8579bb172d4bb612e0aa2aa6b498

commit_message:
NetApp unified driver implementation.

NetApp has growing number of multiple drivers depending on storage families
and technologies. NetApp unified driver simplifies configuration
and provides single entry point for all storage technologies/drivers.
It provides pluggable mechanism to support multiple NetApp technologies
and block drivers related to them. Deprecated 7mode dfm and c mode
webservice based drivers.

blueprint netapp-unified-driver

Change-Id: If7a9923ea02f650cea8a700003ba9438a2b92cab

commit_message:
Fixing a server status race issue

Ensure every test case gets an ACTIVE server.

Using similar solution like used in the
tempest/api/compute/servers/test_server_actions.py.

It is very similar to the way what the testresources
 uses.

Fixing Bug 1170118

Change-Id: I7b3cba72279a266a438d02070c00308f70482f72

commit_message:
Remove explicit distribute depend.

Causes issues with the recent re-merge with setuptools. Advice from
upstream is to stop doing explicit depends.

Change-Id: Ib2c68618368c766e7444e45074bddb01b29752d3

commit_message:
Remove quota whitebox tests

The quota limitation are testable by blackbox tests.
These quota tests are skipped because of issues anyway.

Fixing Bug 1034129

Change-Id: Icaeaed3bb5151ce2057ff3e850e3240c38b2ab81

The Nicira plugin does not require an L3 agent, however the
PUBLIC_BRIDGE is needed by the quantum-debug tool as well as
nicira third_party configuration.

Fixes bug #1190062

Change-Id: Ie60f8f340e034a35a65e54518838c1d751a481a8
'}]
commit_message:
quantum-debug configuration fails on missing PUBLIC_BRIDGE

The Nicira plugin does not require an L3 agent, however the
PUBLIC_BRIDGE is needed by the quantum-debug tool as well as
nicira third_party configuration.

Fixes bug #1190062

Change-Id: Ie60f8f340e034a35a65e54518838c1d751a481a8

commit_message:
Adds openssl-devel to the RPMs dependencies

pyOpenSSL (required by glanceclient) fails to build if openssl
header files are missing.

Change-Id: I3ebce749ee9ca88cbbecc6b7676a086d82670f4d
Fixes: bug #1188650

commit_message:
Raise exception if --nic is specified w/out net-id

When specifying --nic, net-id (UUID) needs to be specified.  This
change ensures that both net-id is provided and that all specified
keys are valid.

Change-Id: I9278a8f76d4e9972bb07fbf41b7973e906f57ba9
Fixes: bug #1191139

'}, {'created': '2013-06-12 21:13:42.000000000', 'message': 'Raise BadRequest if unable to create subnet

The existing create_subnet method iterates over subnets looking for one
that it can use and filters out any errors for overlapping CIDRs. The
problem is if a usable subnet is not found, the code goes on to use an
undeclared variable (body).

This patch saves the last overlapping CIDR exception and raises it if no
usable subnet is found to avoid the undeclared variable usage.

Fixes bug 1186445

Change-Id: I9ba4feada05a65a592bbd04ce8b722200e80b165
'}]
commit_message:
Raise BadRequest if unable to create subnet

The existing create_subnet method iterates over subnets looking for one
that it can use and filters out any errors for overlapping CIDRs. The
problem is if a usable subnet is not found, the code goes on to use an
undeclared variable (body).

This patch saves the last overlapping CIDR exception and raises it if no
usable subnet is found to avoid the undeclared variable usage.

Fixes bug 1186445

Change-Id: I9ba4feada05a65a592bbd04ce8b722200e80b165

commit_message:
Add new libvirt_scrub_logical_volume option

For less security conscious setups, or performance sensitive setups, add
this new option to make it configurable whether to scrub logical volume
or not when deleting the lvm disk.

Change-Id: Ic2722e1d6b5784d7b65f476312d230ee1ed30d93

commit_message:
Refactor conf sample generator script

Optimized grep calls to not create a grep process per file.
Defined variables to enhance readability.

Change-Id: Ic873f2c3b600a737ce54444dec973720c8813285

[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-05-22 20:12:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/30154/1/check/gate-nova-pep8/26689 : SUCCESS in 3m 53s
- http://docs-draft.openstack.org/30154/1/check/gate-nova-docs/20909/doc/build/html/ : SUCCESS in 3m 07s

- http://logs.openstack.org/30154/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-postgres-full/17513 : FAILURE in 51m 30s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/30154/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm-quantum/24515 : SUCCESS in 22m 09s
- http://logs.openstack.org/30154/1/check/gate-grenade-devstack-vm/5309 : FAILURE in 11m 17s (non-voting)
- http://logs.openstack.org/30154/1/check/gate-nova-pylint/12120 : SUCCESS in 9m 59s (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-05-29 11:25:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think I'd like to see more information about what exact failure this fixes ... maybe even with a failing test case

e.g. where exactly in Nova's code are we requiring cidr to be set? could we fix those places to support empty values too?"}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2013-05-29 17:24:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I don't think nova's code requires cidr to be set. It's nova client that requires a cidr to be specified when deleting a rule. It does a get for the security group, then iterates through its rules checking if each rule's attributes match the request (one is cidr, and it always fails when empty). If there's a match, delete is called.

Since nova in general has this notion of cidr for a rule, I thought perhaps there's no harm in translating empty to 0.0.0.0/0, since that's the meaning of empty from the quantum side."}, {'account_id': 7537, 'date': '2013-06-05 08:48:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm slightly confused by the use case here - if you are creating and updating security groups using quantum client, why would you try to delete them using the nova client?

If nova client shows the rules correctly, and you can manipulate them using quantum client, is this patch required?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2013-06-06 12:04:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Ok, the novaclient code is https://github.com/openstack/python-novaclient/blob/f67c5e0/novaclient/v1_1/shell.py#L1957

I guess this does imply that the understood semantics of the API is all rules have a cidr property'}, {'account_id': 7537, 'date': '2013-06-11 14:37:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1921, 'date': '2013-06-11 14:49:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 5652, 'date': '2013-06-11 17:06:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:08:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:08:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

Starting gate jobs.

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-22 19:18:20.000000000', 'message': 'translates empty remote_ip_prefix to valid cidr for nova

Quantum allows empty remote_ip_prefix to mean "any host"
but Nova uses a CIDR as part of each rule.

Fixes bug 1180828

Change-Id: I4983515ccd0cc621491d63e59d6ab6ac4dd74b6a
'}]
commit_message:
translates empty remote_ip_prefix to valid cidr for nova

Quantum allows empty remote_ip_prefix to mean "any host"
but Nova uses a CIDR as part of each rule.

Fixes bug 1180828

Change-Id: I4983515ccd0cc621491d63e59d6ab6ac4dd74b6a

[{'created': '2013-05-20 16:45:36.000000000', 'message': "Don't snat all traffic when force_snat_range set

When using /proc/sys/net/bridge/bridge-nf-call-iptables=1, bridged
traffic gets snatted even though it is being bridged out to an
external gateway. This can lead to async routes where traffic
goes out the fixed network and comes back on the float network
and can lead to packets being blocked by firewalls. Work around
this problem by only fallback snatting when the traffic is
going to one of the force_snat_ranges. If force_snat_range is not
set it defaults to the existing behavior of snatting all traffic

commit_message:
Don't snat all traffic when force_snat_range set

When using /proc/sys/net/bridge/bridge-nf-call-iptables=1, bridged
traffic gets snatted even though it is being bridged out to an
external gateway. This can lead to asymmetric routes where traffic
goes out the fixed network and comes back on the float network
and can lead to packets being blocked by firewalls. Work around
this problem by only fallback snatting when the traffic is
going to one of the force_snat_ranges. If force_snat_range is not
set it defaults to the existing behavior of snatting all traffic
that doesn't hit an earlier rule.

Fixes bug 1182143

Change-Id: If496dad2308a68a6a4a9fd43d695943bc5034ac4

commit_message:
hardcode pbr and d2to1 versions

Hard code pbr to d2to1 to >=0.2.10,<0.3 and
pbr to >=0.5,<0.6 for consistency across projects.

Change-Id: I7163bef37934856e5f80df336044f8ebcb690797
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
override tempest http_image variable in the gate

one of the tempest tests is to ensure glance can download something
over http, defaulting to the upstream cirros image. In the gate
that url ends up unstable on the network.

To get around this, feed devstack a tempest variable which sets
this to the horizon url. That's a valid http url. Because we don't
test for content, this is good enough for the test.

Rev 2: hardcode horizon to 127.0.0.1, the previous variable wasn't
set.

Partial fix for bug #1190623 once the devstack change lands.

Change-Id: Ifd94ace4b07a5ab9d20af7088e38420e9f3aab88

commit_message:
Update and add notifiers in create volume

1. Change status from 'creating' to 'available' when the volume is created
2. Add a notifier when it fails to create the volume

Implements: notifiers for create volume
Fixes: bug #1190754
Change-Id: I3a7d118630b32cfa7efb6bc8984418ca9836764a

'}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-06-09 07:53:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2013-06-09 15:17:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-06-09 19:02:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Why xml_to_data and not xml_to_dict? It's a dict that is returned, not just "data"...'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-06-11 21:17:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

dict is special word.

If you implement a more generic service functions, you will not know what is represented by the data.

data = xml_to_data(foo)

It is a likely situation and you do not need think about any more fancy name.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-06-11 22:55:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I honestly see no value in this change for this change's sake. If this becomes part of a patch series that uses this function in a more interesting way, I'd be ok with it. Otherwise I think this is just churn."}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-06-11 23:46:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

dict is a special word, sure, but that doesn't mean you can't use it in a method or func name... I mean, id is a special name and you still see lots of get_id() methods around...

But, overall, I just think this is window-dressing and not really helping improve readability of the code."}, {'account_id': 5292, 'date': '2013-06-12 02:33:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Just to add my 2c. I think that having a function named to imply that it returns json when it doesn't is worth fixing because it is very misleading to those who are new to the codebase who may then try applying json utils functions to what is returned. It did confuse me for a while.

Perhaps xml_to_data is not the best name, but its a lot better than xml_to_json"}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-06-12 08:09:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@Jay Pipes:

The even bigger picture here is the documentation generation.'}, {'account_id': 6796, 'date': '2013-06-12 08:27:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

In a previous comment I suggest changing the in-function variable name from json to data too but I noticed one more thing.

The function is used by other clients (see volume) so
maybe we should also move it outside the compute tree?

Can these changes be part of a bigger "refactor"?'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-06-12 11:28:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

right, like I said, this change on it's own doesn't do anything for me. My vote would be different if this was part of a patch series that it made sense to support.

I also really think that data is less descriptive than json. The output of this is a nested python data structure which is the python equiv of the json. json.loads, json.dump works on this data structure with no additional changes. Just calling it data removes information that the above works and needs to continue to work.

Why not just document the function instead in a patch, if the issue is clarity."}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-06-12 12:57:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@sdague:

If you think it should one change, I have some additional question.

The xml module classes are imported two many times just for several small utility.

What is your opinion about importing them as module, and prefixing every xml.Element xml.Document in the code with xml.

The other thing what should be used in similar way is the utils after a small computerization. (In a little different way I attempted it long time ago)

In readability and namespace utilization view point our other imports are fine.

I do not have a true argument to import them as module in  tempest context.

Do we want to remove the module import rules form the HACKING.rst ?'}, {'account_id': 5803, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:26:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

I will do it in one change'}]

commit_message:
xml_to_json renamed xml_to_data

xml_to_json functions return value not json at all.
It is a python "native" data structure.

Doc string extended as well.

Change-Id: Ibb38d72cfb1f3453953406f3df39d412b7396bec

commit_message:
api: Add initial support for an actions subpath

Initial support for an actions subpath, which will be the access-point
for non-lifecycle operations on stacks, e.g suspend/resume
The API interface is similar to the Server Admin Actions nova extension
which will be the primary underlying interface used for this functionality

blueprint: stack-suspend-resume
Change-Id: If8ac7145c77b0f26779d9e9d4c50854003554546

subject: Redhat family doesn't have dbus service
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-07 12:56:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build succeeded.

- http://logs.openstack.org/32127/1/check/gate-cookbook-openstack-compute-chef-lint/203 : SUCCESS in 4m 01s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32127/1/check/gate-cookbook-openstack-compute-chef-style/67 : SUCCESS in 4m 37s
- http://logs.openstack.org/32127/1/check/gate-cookbook-openstack-compute-chef-unit/203 : SUCCESS in 5m 01s
'}, {'account_id': 7220, 'date': '2013-06-07 17:03:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Sure enough, this is a sill RH-ism.
[root@alop-rhel ~]# ps -ef | grep dbus
dbus      1379     1  0 16:58 ?        00:00:00 dbus-daemon --system
root      1849  1808  0 17:02 pts/0    00:00:00 grep dbus
[root@alop-rhel ~]# service dbus-daemon status
dbus-daemon: unrecognized service
[root@alop-rhel ~]# service messagebus status
messagebus (pid  1379) is running...'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2013-06-07 17:09:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Instead of repeating the service block with two not/only_if guards, can we just add a variable for the service name that is switched based on platform, like we have for, say, Python package names?

That way, the different messagebus/dbus service name could be set in attributes/default.rb and the block would simply become:

 service node["openstack"]["compute"]["dbus_service_name"] do
   action [:enable, :start]
 end

Also, please add a ChefSpec test to the relevant spec files to validate the changed behaviour.

Thanks!

-jay'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-07 12:51:15.000000000', 'message': "Redhat family doesn't have dbus service

The dbus service in RHEL, CentOS and Fedora is called messagebus,
which causes the libvirt.rb recipe to fail. This fixes that.

Change-Id: I0216569c0fa91c5d2dfcea4cabc942bd9f2441dc
"}]
commit_message:
Redhat family doesn't have dbus service

The dbus service in RHEL, CentOS and Fedora is called messagebus,
which causes the libvirt.rb recipe to fail. This fixes that.

Change-Id: I0216569c0fa91c5d2dfcea4cabc942bd9f2441dc

commit_message:
Adds live migration support to cells API

Fixes bug 1153087

DocImpact: Cells now allows live migration within a cell,
but not between cells.

Conflicts:
	nova/tests/compute/test_compute_cells.py

Change-Id: Ic8777c376883eaf6ff9cb4b379e0bacbfe5635b7

commit_message:
Retry failed deletes.

Operators report that deleting instance files from NFS sometimes fails.
This review implements a simple retry periodic task which attempts to
delete these files several times before giving up.

Resolves bug 1040110.

Change-Id: I465be6421633e22e3185b3b5eec1d037ae2e6d54

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-30 00:33:19.000000000', 'message': "Add the 'metadata' and 'description' to the DB.

Based on the API v1 spec, the following changes:
- Add the 'description' and 'metadata' fields to chassis.
- Add 'metadata' to nodes.
- Rename 'extra' to 'metadata' on ports.

Change-Id: I8e98b2921958d008bceb2eb29fcb4c93378d89af
"}, {'created': '2013-05-30 08:52:40.000000000', 'message': 'Add 'description' and 'extra' fields to chassis.

commit_message:
Add 'extra' fields to chassis.

Based on the API v1 spec, chassis should store a
metadata-like "extra" field.

Change-Id: I8e98b2921958d008bceb2eb29fcb4c93378d89af

There was a dependent patch but it got lost in a rebase. I will fix that now.

This solution was preferred because its lighter weight than something involving sqlalchemy. It also keeps deployment simple. why do the cases you mentioned need persistent storage?  My concern here, is abusing this tool.  Currently all state either is either in the central DB or comes from information the machines are gathering in real time, not from a distributed persistent stores.   Adding in distributed persistent stores can potentially makes things much more complicated if we are not careful.   At the very least I would like to see this feature better documented for what it should and should not be used for. 


Also http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12289759/thread-safe-persistent-key-value-store-for-python"}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2013-06-05 00:31:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-05 03:48:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Works for me

(1 inline comment)

Don't like it from the point of view of a nova operator:

- It introduces additional dependency on a common, transient resource - not fun to debug in case of issues. DB at least has a binlog of changes.
- It should probably be locking externally as a generic utility - see inline (I expect lots more code using this once/if it gets merged).
- It's yet another place that needs to be checked for consistency on a live system - current database is bad enough for this.

Regarding proposed use cases: Checksums - ".sha/.md5" files are quite good for that and never need to change - alternatively there's a cache module that could be useful. Late deletes - commented on that review - if it's only 3 retries, why do they need to be persistent?'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2013-06-07 18:24:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 10: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Implement a simple local store.

This store is deliberately unstructured. It is up to the user to handle
versioning and so forth. In the use cases I can think of, its just a
list, so shouldn't require much work.

It doesn't make sense to store this data in the central nova DB,
because if you lose the disks on a compute node, this store is
intended for work which would no longer be required.

Change-Id: I4c49a0f3e7e0039649b8eb80718aae67c78e10d8

subject: Redefined status fields as enums.
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 261, 'name': 'Salvatore Orlando', 'email': 'salv.orlando@gmail.com', 'username': 'salvatore-orlando'}, {'_account_id': 2592, 'name': 'Mark McClain', 'email': 'mark@mcclain.xyz', 'username': 'markmcclain'}, {'_account_id': 4362, 'name': 'Salvatore Orlando', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 6447, 'name': 'Avishay Balderman', 'email': 'avishayb@radware.com', 'username': 'avishayb'}, {'_account_id': 6623, 'name': 'Roman Prykhodchenko', 'email': 'me@romcheg.me', 'username': 'prykhodchenko'}, {'_account_id': 6849, 'name': 'Roman Podoliaka', 'email': 'roman.podoliaka@gmail.com', 'username': 'rpodolyaka'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 261, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (3 inline comments)

This change does not introduce any incompatibility nor changes anything in the way the API works.
However, it assumes each Quantum resource has the same pool of statuses. We do not know if this can be true in the future, and it's already not true now (eg: only the lb resources support the PENDING_XXX statuses). Also, plugins are allowed to extend the pool of values, as clearly stated in the API reference.

I agree using enumerations is an improvement (albeit minor). Therefore I would consider one of the following:

1 - Use SQL enums, and have distinct status enumerations for different resources; please note that this might still cause a problem if a plugin wants to define custom status values.

2 - Keep storing data as a strings, but use python enums (or the best approximation python offers to enums) for the values to be stored."}, {'account_id': 2592, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

I think using m2 as an alias for models_v2 could be confusing (especially with ML2 development occurring).

I'd also like Salvatore's opinion now since this change implicitly adds new status states to core resources (Networks, etc)."}, {'account_id': 6447, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Roman
It looks good to me. However I think Mark mentioned that the "status as enum" is a cross Quantum concern (for now you covered lbaas but there are more Quantum entities to cover).'}, {'account_id': 6623, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

In patch set 3 I defined status as a property to control assignments and got rid of validation on the database level. This will allow plugins to extend the existing set of values for status.'}, {'account_id': 6623, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6623, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: (1 inline comment)

Salvatore, Mark, Avishay,
Can you please review this patch?'}, {'account_id': 6623, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Having a validation on the DB level is a feature we'd like to have, I guess. However, every plugin has to modify the database every time it's been enabled or disabled. This is quite dangerous and currently we don't have any mechanism for performing that anyway."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

code review expired after 2 weeks of no activity, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button  under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-06-15 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Abandoned

pep8 failures look legitimate, additionally there are many typos in the docstrings.

Is this part of a blueprint?"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-29 21:11:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Really would like to see more details of the use case this is addressing.  

I don't see anything in here that checks that the user has instances in the specified group - so it feels as if this might cause scheduling interactions between different users. 

We already have the base filter_scheduler consuming the "group" scheduler hint and affinity / anti-affinity filters, not sure if it would confuse things further if another part of the scheduler consumes the same hint.'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-07 06:03:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

response to Boris's comment"}, {'account_id': 2667, 'date': '2013-05-08 05:38:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Regarding Phil's comments:
1) regarding security -- it doesn't seem to be an issue, since all the filters/weights are running under user context, and "see" only instances of the corresponding tenant. This is also the case for the affinity filters, for example.
2) I do see how this kind of weight functions might be useful and complementary to the group filters. While the latter are hard constraints, the former may allow applying similar criteria as soft constraints.'}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-05-10 00:24:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

@Alex  Thanks for the reply.   So I can see now the "group" is only significant in the context of the user starting the request, so that negates my first comment.

I do also see the use case of spreading evenly all instances in a group for the user - but the groupAntiAffinityFilter already does sort of the same thing but with a hard limit of one instance per host from the group.    It seems to me that this weigher and that filter are therefore mutually exclusive, but there is nothing in the code to detect and warn of that condition   (or even in the commit comment come to that).  So I'm keeping a -1 for now as I think this could lead to confusion in its current form.'}, {'account_id': 7331, 'date': '2013-05-14 09:57:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thank you for your replies!

@Alex I think, you're right. Security is not an issue.

@Phil It seems to me that using affinity filters and this weigher together would not cause problems. In that case affinity filters will exclude group hosts, and then weigher will set other hosts weight to 0. So, one of remaining hosts will be chosen. If you prefer, I will add a warning message in case of booting instance using affinity filter and this weigher together."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-05-22 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

commit_message:
Add GroupEvenSpreadWeigher for nova scheduler

GroupEvenSpreadWeigher allows to spread instances from definite
group between all accessible hosts. It is necessary to pass a
scheduler hint, using group as key and name of the group as value,
when booting an instance.

Add tests for this weigher.

DocImpact

Implements blueprint add-group-even-spread-weigher

Change-Id: I35d56c791111c2f44a22c69a7a543b9c0d5f3612

commit_message:
Replace password to "***" in the debug message

Use regex pattern to replace password to "***" for both env vars and
request body output

Also includes a minor refactor to move the code up in the file as
suggested by termie and henry regarding the review comments in
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/26487/
(Original Change-Id: I890415c755dd383749f2d4382f53d0b3a6badc6c)

Fix bug 1166697

Change-Id: I671ea25cca78b4dea1fbf2e63c89b82912279f2d

commit_message:
Fix quota checks while resizing up by admin

Fixes LP 1184594

Fixing a bug when admin issues a resize up for a user, it checks for
admin's quota instead of user's quota.

Change-Id: Ida5db9039396df0a08c699711b72882e2ef136f8

kvs driver for tokens is not a production quality storage method.
The shortcomings of using kvs as storage driver for tokens:
    1. It requires load balancer to persist connections to a single
keystone server by token.
    2. The memory will grow out of control until token_flush is run.
    3. At some point kvs lookups get very slow because there are millions
of keys in the dict.

commit_message:
Using sql as default driver for tokens

kvs driver for tokens is not a production quality storage method.
The shortcomings of using kvs as storage driver for tokens:
    1. It requires load balancer to persist connections to a single
keystone server by token.
    2. The memory will grow out of control until token_flush is run.
    3. At some point kvs lookups get very slow because there are millions
of keys in the dict.
    4. Process restart invalidates all tokens.

Fixes: bug #1188370
Change-Id: Ic726e12d798b843412158a7b92f5e3e3a654811f

commit_message:
Create Port object.

1. Added the model of a Port.
2. Defined __all__ for ironic.objects to simplify
   accessing the models.
3. Made @objectify universal for all objects.

Partially implements blueprint: ironic-object-model

Change-Id: Iec88310811d0e17903b5182d08e293dd4d0967d0

commit_message:
Add uuid to Port DB model.

This patch adds uuid column to ports table.
Fixes: bug #1190916

Change-Id: Ie7a7c1150a863ee42f382eaf1393a2e3961434df

commit_message:
Use Python 3.x compatible except: construct

Per (proposed) H203 check, convert all uses of
the deprecated except x,y: construct to except
x as y:, which works with any Python version >= 2.6

Change-Id: I5528dc556f3ef8d356e01d59df04ba57f66c95b7

commit_message:
Remove usage of locals() for formatting from cinder.api.*

Using of locals() for formatting string is a nasty thing because:
1) It is not so clear as using explicit dicts
2) It could produce hidden errors during refactoring
3) Changing name of variable causes change in message
4) Creating a lot of unused variables

Fix bug 1171936

Change-Id: Id6a900899db328be067b8139a49c12ce802dd415

commit_message:
Replace utils.to_bytes() with strutils.to_bytes()

The to_bytes() function have moved to oslo.

commit_message:
Provide keystone CLI man page.

Resolves: bug 1185142
Implements blueprint: clients-man-pages

Provide basic but hopefully useful man page.

shell.rst was merged into and replaced by the man page in HTML docs.

Change-Id: I0a90e4638cc7e4ed9c02c5abd7d84a4079e5f50d

commit_message:
Add missing tests for provider_fw_rule_* methods

There was no tests in test_db_api for provider_fw_rule_*
methods.

Add tests to ensure that all works.

blueprint db-api-tests

Change-Id: Ia137ffcfcba3f663a177386775147a25d6716980

commit_message:
Cleanup shell's authentication check.

The original logic for whether shell had enough information to
authenticate a user was confusing and will be very difficult to extend
to other forms of authentication.

Change-Id: I88763a651e494e60070a30f0824505acb09310cb

commit_message:
Added first Savanna Controller level validation

* It checks if user configs has wrong applicable targtes and config names

Change-Id: Ie8979103e888696e2f16654abd910ffdd281d7d8
NOTE: This is just for simplifying testing purposes and maybe changed soon

Also, the following code was removed:

exec {"create_partition-${name}":
  command    => "parted -s -a optimal ${base_dir}/${name} mkpart primary 0% 100%",
  path       => ['/usr/bin','/sbin','/bin'],
  onlyif     => ["parted ${base_dir}/${name} print|tail -2|grep 'Number'"],
  require    => Exec["create_partition_label-${name}"],
}

should it be wrapped in some configurable logic?'}, {'account_id': 2265, 'date': '2013-06-11 23:08:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Hi Yu,

We're pretty eager to get this merged as-is. Can you let me know if it works for you?"}, {'account_id': 1607, 'date': '2013-06-12 04:26:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Sorry for reply so late. 
I am pretty sure this works well in production environment, I use this to deploy a big swift cluster, each node has ten disks. 
And I consulting the swift dev whether or not to make partition for each disk.  It's reasonable to use the whole disk instead of making several partitions on a disk. For example, we would use sdb instead of using sdb1. 
So I remove create_partition-${name} define and it has been tested in production environment."}, {'account_id': 1607, 'date': '2013-06-12 04:29:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1607, 'date': '2013-06-12 06:14:48.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-12 06:16:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

commit_message:
Add swift::storage::disk to support disk device.

It aim to support to use the disk device as the swift storage backend,
this pathch contains:
    * a new define with three params
    * annotations and examples for this define
    * a new spec test

Change-Id: I92f13992a02b9cff0f29bde3266a92f37bf63d13

Shouldn't Berksfile.lock be in the .gitignore list?"}, {'account_id': 216, 'date': '2013-06-13 17:22:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hi Justin,

Originally we git ignored it b/c it contained FS paths in it, so if I generated it, you would have my homedir path in the lock file.  Also, Berkshelf didn't actually use it properly.

With Berkshelf 2.0 it actually uses the lock file, just as bundler uses the Gemfile.lock.  Take a look at this review to see why I added it.  If I don't add the lock file, the tests will not pass.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/32301/"}, {'account_id': 1032, 'date': '2013-06-13 20:30:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Clearer registraton LWRP tests

This is a much clearer way to test LWRPs are executed with
the proper options.  The previous approach was hacky, and
relied upon too much stubbing and ruby magik.  Also, updated
to berkshelf 2.0 where Berksfile.lock is respected.  This
is necessary for berkshelf to lock to the proper cookbook
deps in openstack's CI system.

Change-Id: Ia912efffa137a75352423e7571cb74bca9ab1b5d

commit_message:
Impl bulk ops for instance interop helper.

* cleanup InstanceInteropHelper class;
* add support for bulk ops using context managers.

For example:

with instance.remote as remote:
    remote.execute_command('hostname')
    remote.send_file_to('/etc/hosts', hosts_file)

Improves blueprint instance-interop-helper

Change-Id: I806c7adad787e669b6f62e5f02494b554ea53bde

Replace use of locals() with explicit values for formatting strings.

commit_message:
Fix _drop_unique_constraint_in_sqlite() function.

We got incorrect unique constrains in function
_drop_unique_constraint_in_sqlite().
New function `_get_unique_constraints_in_sqlite()` was added to fix it.

Change-Id: Iebb4c0e6c3e6a069ba5cde2fdb2a2ff1200b826f
Fixes: bug 1184526

this is so. I get the following output when I run this.

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/30491/ doesn't work for me, I commented on the review that got pushed through anyways.

I agree the -d is extra boiler plate and shouldn't really be needed. But the testing framework must be able to support debugging of tests. Without the -d it is currently impossible to put a pdb.set_trace into a test.

Thanks for reviewing this. I will address your issues when I get some time to work on this again."}, {'account_id': 4355, 'date': '2013-05-28 07:40:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Hi John,

1. six is installed in pip-requires, I haven't removed it from test-requires

2. What tests were failing for you. I am seeing randomly failing tests, mostly around test_notifier, something like:

======================================================================
FAIL: cinder.tests.test_volume.VolumeTestCase.test_create_delete_snapshot
----------------------------------------------------------------------
_StringException: Empty attachments:
  pythonlogging:''-1
  stderr
  stdout

pythonlogging:'': {{{
volume volume-b9e15b66-ab02-40e7-9558-7e02a3b339af: creating
volume volume-b9e15b66-ab02-40e7-9558-7e02a3b339af: created successfully
Clear capabilities
}}}

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/opt/stack/cinder/cinder/tests/test_volume.py", line 439, in test_create_delete_snapshot
    self.assertEquals(len(test_notifier.NOTIFICATIONS), 2)
MismatchError: 0 != 2

This seems to be cause the tests are now run in parallel, some are stepping over each other. I would like to know why I don't see them in nova. Let me know if you are seeing different test failures. I will try and get to the bottom of it.

Michael'}, {'account_id': 6969, 'date': '2013-05-30 16:53:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

John, yes testr by default runs tests in parallel and the default concurrency is 0 meaning that it looks up how many cpus you have and runs that many processes.

The vm I am using to run the tests has 8 cores, and I regularly see test errors, and I don't see them now when I leave the concurrency at 1.

I will hopefully have gotten it to run in Jenkins with the last patch."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-06-06 17:13:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 14: Doesn't seem to work

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-05-23 16:23:06.000000000', 'message': 'Fix up the test framework

When trying to test an bug the cinder test framework was
running all the tests when I just wanted one to run.

After looking into this, there are bug reports for moving
cinder to using testtools, and testr tool for testing. Instead
of fixing the initial problem in nose I tried to move cinder to
testtools and testr. I copied a fair bit of code from nova
to get this to work. This way at least if some one makes an
improvement to the nova test framework cinder can improve
also.

Before this patch run_test.sh was finding and running 1345 test
and now it is finding 1366 tests :-). Although I am having problems
getting some to pass.

This is still work in progress as I have some tests failing.

Fixes: bug 1183434
Fixes: bug 1177924
Fixes: bug 1179009

Change-Id: I5e10b55c5b236eb81a6a3e0e9ea56af8ca4ef8e1

commit_message:
Fix up the test framework

When trying to test a bug the cinder test framework was
running all the tests when I just wanted one to run.

Instead of fixing this problem in nose I tried to move cinder to
testr. I copied a fair bit of code from nova to get this to work.
This way at least if some one makes an improvement to the nova
test framework cinder can improve here also.

Note that now all the tests a thread safe. Added a concurrency argument
to run_tests.sh that defaults to 1. You can specify your own level then
and take the risk of intermittent failures. Tell jenkins to use a
concurrency level of 1 to avoid failing gate jobs.

Note One of these tests is broken and I have disabled for now. There
is a bug for this here: https://bugs.launchpad.net/cinder/+bug/1173266

Note: cinder.api.openstack.FaultWrapper is deprecated and is causing
a circular import when I try and import cinder.tests.test_wsgi. This
is fixed by only importing the openstack.FaultWrapper during the
__init__ phase of the wsgi middleware.

Fixes: bug 1183434
Fixes: bug 1177924

Change-Id: I5e10b55c5b236eb81a6a3e0e9ea56af8ca4ef8e1

commit_message:
Naming instance directory by uuid in VMware Hyper.

Like Libvirt Hyper, Using EC2 template for naming instance
directory may cause conflict. we follow what Libvirt does to use
instance uuid instead of EC2 template naming. To keep backwards
compability, when fails to find a instance by uuid, fall back to use
EC2 name.

Fix bug #1186944

Change-Id: Iaba099225a9b3b0390cae4c5fbd82d7e6c11f0e0

'}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-06-13 03:38:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

what do you think use try...except inside get_param, which could keep codes clean at account/server.py'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-13 03:57:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Eh, I'm not a fan of that approach.

Right now, we've got a few different expectations in get_param().

* returns None if param absent
* returns param if param present and valid UTF-8
* raises UnicodeDecodeError if param present and not valid UTF-8

So, if we're going to take the exception away, how would we indicate an invalid parameter? If we stick to strings, we have to return one that's invalid UTF-8, and the only way I know of to detect invalid UTF-8 is to try to decode it and catch the UnicodeDecodeError.

That leaves us with non-string values. I guess we could return False or some other sentinel value for invalid Unicode, but now that leaves us with code like this:

    alpha = get_param(req, 'alpha')
    beta = get_param(req, 'beta')
    gamma = get_param(req, 'gamma')
    # ... and so on
    omega = get_param(req, 'omega')

    if alpha is False or beta is False or gamma is False or ... or omega is False:
        return HTTPBadRequest(whatever)

I don't see how that's any cleaner than wrapping up all your get_param() calls in a try/except block."}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-06-13 04:12:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

for the case of non-utf8 encoded strings, return None or False in get_param(), and you could keep account/server.py and container/server.py work without change. Is this kind of cleaner?

BTW, your reply also have a good format, that a kind of MarkDown syntax? Is there any docs for that?'}, {'account_id': 6198, 'date': '2013-06-13 21:25:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2013-06-13 22:25:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@Kun Huang:

Returning False from get_param() would be fine if I wanted to ignore invalid UTF-8 values in the 'format' parameter, but I don't. I want to return a 400 response instead of silently ignoring a bogus format, so I end up having to check for present-but-invalid anyway."}, {'account_id': 6835, 'date': '2013-06-14 01:54:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

got it! no more argus'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2013-06-14 14:05:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-12 22:58:36.000000000', 'message': "Fix 503 on account/container HEAD w/invalid format.

A HEAD request to /v1/a[/c]?format=%FF would result in a 503 since
there was an unhandled UnicodeDecodeError. Now it doesn't.

bug 1190395

Change-Id: I4d8ec677092617391fe154a25f22d919536a72a5
"}]
commit_message:
Fix 503 on account/container HEAD w/invalid format.

A HEAD request to /v1/a[/c]?format=%FF would result in a 503 since
there was an unhandled UnicodeDecodeError. Now it doesn't.

bug 1190395

Change-Id: I4d8ec677092617391fe154a25f22d919536a72a5

'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2013-04-02 12:16:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Sorry David - but on second thought - I am not sure this is good behaviour. This will make it impossible for the admin to decrease quota limits for users/tenants that are over the new quota.

This is certainly not what we want and in that case the current behaviour is actually not a bug.

Warning will be better, but as Kevin mentioned in the bug - this might be tricky to implement."}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-04-02 12:53:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Good point for the admin operation view.
So do we still need this additional check and just add some warning message in log file? or this validation is not necessary?'}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2013-04-02 13:08:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ideally - we should be able to notify users that their quota has been decreased and that they will not be able to do what they think they might be able to do without their failing jobs telling them that.

This may not need to be automated, but would be good to let the admin know that certain tenants/users will be immediately blocked by this action. Some ideas:

* maybe leave this as is in the patch, but have the api return all the users this fails for, and add a --force to still make it possible to change it like before the patch.

* Leave it as is now, but have the api call return the list of immediately affected users.

All of these would have to wait for H tho.

These are only a few options with pros and cons. I'd bring this up on the dev list and see what the community thinks."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-04-02 14:48:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

"}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-04-02 16:09:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-04-02 16:10:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Kevin,
Do you have any update for the Nikola's comments?
Looks like add new '--force' to enforce the quota's change is a better solution."}, {'account_id': 679, 'date': '2013-04-02 16:39:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Thanks for fixing the tests.  I agree that a --force option is good.  I don't know if there is any way to notify a user of a change in their quota, but I doubt it, at least at present.  And H is open right now, so no worries there.

You should keep in mind the possibility of the implementation of Boson or something like that; that is, quotas may end up being stored outside of nova, and updated there as well.  I don't think that has any significant impact on this patch, but it means that what you're adding could potentially disappear in the future…"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2013-04-02 16:51:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Doesn't seem to work

Yes, I'm referring to using an external resource to make all quota decisions, rather than in-nova quotas.  There is a proposed session at the summit to discuss quotas, and I don't know what the result of that discussion will be, but I expect that it will not get done, except in trial version, by the end of the Havana cycle."}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-04-08 07:13:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hi Kevin, at least for now, we still need this fix because it's our product expectation, for your new proposal I think we can continue to discuss on how to improve the pre-check function."}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-04-08 07:24:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Hi Nikola, sorry I didn't get your point for the inline comment, do you mean I need add more log to indicate the user need use '--force' to update quota if the new quota exceed the already used?
For the new extension, I really do not think it is necessary for these a bit validation changes."}, {'account_id': 5511, 'date': '2013-04-08 08:04:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

I'm not sure off the top of my head which repositories those will be, but you can check with the CI team; they'll be able to help you out with that."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-04-23 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2013-04-23 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-04-23 06:05:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Restored

Still pending on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/27043/ approve to temporary disable test cases in tempest.'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2013-04-25 17:32:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

so from a tempest point of view I don't want to disable the tests until this patch has 2 +2s from Nova to get in (because of the possibilities that other breaks could slide in). After that we'll turn off the tests immediately."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-04-25 18:09:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

the code seems reasonable to me, although this is slightly different api behavior. I wonder if we should just make this change for the v3 api. A user of the code will have no way of knowing what the resulting behavior of passing in update without force will do. Perhaps this is just a bug in the existing implementation so we could just consider it a fix and release note it but I'm not convinced that is the case."}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-04-26 03:23:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Hi Vish,
Do you mean I need enhance the error message like following at #140 if the new quota is greater than already used?
msg = _("Quota value %(value)s for %(key)s are "
              "greater than already used and reserved "
              "%(quota_used)s, use '--force' to force update quota.") % locals()
raise webob.exc.HTTPBadRequest(explanation=msg)

And update nova doc according this change as well?'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2013-04-26 23:37:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

no i mean there is no way for a user to know if they need to pass in force in advance. You can't query the extension list to see if --force is allowed which means that calling nova quota-update will always be unsafe. If there were a new extension to query then you could know whether or not it was safe to call nova quota-update."}, {'account_id': 6526, 'date': '2013-04-27 02:37:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I get your point, maybe I only need extend the 'quota show' to do the same things like I did in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/25520/ and let end user know how many quotas are in used, is it enough?"}, {'account_id': 1501, 'date': '2013-04-27 06:56:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

I think what Vish means is that as you're in effect adding additional parameters to an API call, then this needs to be a new API extension, so that the client can tell if a particular system supports this new behavior. 

The new extension simply exists just to configure this new feature on or off. 

This similar change might help explain (although I still haven't got the unit test working)

commit_message:
Enhance the validation of the quotas update

Need check whether the already used and reserved exceeds the new quota
before update it.

DocImpact
Implements a validation to validate whether already used and reserved
quota exceeds the new quota when run 'nova quota-update', it will throw
error if the quota exceeds. This check will be ignored if admin want to
force update when run 'nova quota-update' with additional option
'--force'.
This validation help admin to be aware of whether the quotas are
oversold when they try to update quota and also provide an option
'--force' to allow admin force update the quotas.

Fix bug 1160749

Change-Id: Iba3cee0f0d92cf2e6d64bc83830b0091992d1ee9

This patch updates that file.

Ceilometer uses the admin URL registered in keystone to poll object store.
Usually the url is like: http://<host>:<port>, in some cases, user might
register the url like: http://<host>:<port>/v1 or http://<host>:<port>/v1/AUTH
_%(tenant_id)s
Ceilometer shall get the url registered in keystone and populate it to the
http://<host>:<port>/v1/AUTH_%(tenant_id)s style

Change the url population process the enhance the fault-tolerant capability
of Ceilometer

commit_message:
Ceilometer may generate wrong format swift url in some situations

Ceilometer uses the admin URL registered in keystone to poll object store.
Usually the url is like: http://<host>:<port>, in some cases, user might
register the url like: http://<host>:<port>/v1
Ceilometer shall get the url registered in keystone and populate it to the
http://<host>:<port>/v1/AUTH_%(tenant_id)s style

Change the url population process the enhance the fault-tolerant capability
of Ceilometer

Change-Id: I3ec6ab0c330e35a2fd6bab36b8a2f43aee883b6d
Fixes: Bug 1183704

[{'created': '2013-06-03 23:53:19.000000000', 'message': "Fix token purging for memcache for user token index.

When issuing a new token, purge all expired tokens from the user's
token index list.

New Options:
* max_compare_and_set_retry:
        The number of retries that will be attempted when performing
        an update of the user_record or the revocation-list record.
        This is relevant due to the use of CAS (compare and set)
        function of the memcache client. This allows for multiple
        keystone processes/wsgi/etc to run without worry of race
        conditions clobbering the lists.

DocImpact - New Options.

Change-Id: I9441105b1e46982b0354bccbf8297daaaa1904b2
Fixes: bug #1171985

commit_message:
Fix token purging for memcache for user token index.

When issuing a new token, purge all expired tokens from the user's
token index list.

New Options:
* max_compare_and_set_retry:
        The number of retries that will be attempted when performing
        an update of the user_record or the revocation-list record.
        This is relevant due to the use of CAS (compare and set)
        function of the memcache client. This allows for multiple
        keystone processes/wsgi/etc to run without worry of race
        conditions clobbering the lists.

DocImpact - New Options.

Change-Id: I9441105b1e46982b0354bccbf8297daaaa1904b2
Fixes: bug #1171985

@russ: I would thing that the extensions mechanism in keystone is not just here for internal extension but allow people to plug into it from the outside. I am not adding the headers for the sake of just adding but to actually be able to access them from my extension. I have this extension here :

https://github.com/chmouel/keystone-legacyv1-extension

which expose v1 (i.e: swift v1/rackspace cloud before openstack) auth to keystone, the way that works is going via headers and I can't access those if they are not being passed.

I don't plans to merge the legacyv1 to keystone (I don't think keystone would want it) and think it's the only extension that may need access to headers."}, {'account_id': 866, 'date': '2013-03-26 09:16:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

commit_message:
Allow request headers access in app context.

- Give extensions access to request headers in app context.
- Implements: blueprint allow-access-to-headers-for-extension.

Change-Id: I22bba172a8ceaba9260487666172586c45aa95d4

commit_message:
Ensure flavor_ref_alt is different from flavor_ref

For tempest, server resize tests needs different values
for flavors to pass. Ensure different values in tempest.conf
for flavor_ref_alt and flavor_ref.

Change-Id: I2f8ee92967abc767637e334ae483b540dd7d5b78
Fix: bug 1187768

Change-Id: I5538239db4b2fde83be2390014504e35ccd7c0d3

commit_message:
Fix ring validate with device prior to rebalance.

A builder file with some devices added but before rebalance() is called
should be invalid (in the sense that validate() raises
RingValidationError instead of TypeError).

Change-Id: I5538239db4b2fde83be2390014504e35ccd7c0d3

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-14 01:33:12.000000000', 'message': 'Better escaping for GET /v1/a?format=xml.

Commit 8f9b135 fixed a bug where an XML attribute could have arbitrary
characters jammed into it, resulting in a document with arbitrary
tags... and it did remove the ability to get an arbitrary XML document
out of the object server. However, it left a couple of ways to get a
malformed XML document, one example of which is an account named ".

This fixes up the remaining ways and ensures you always get a
well-formed XML document in the account-listing response. Also, it
adds a unit test for the escaping of the container name; this was
already working, just untested.

If you look in the discussion for bug 1183884, you'll see that the
review comments there are basically "seems good, but could use a unit
test". (The astute reader will note that I am one of the guilty
parties in that review.)

I found this bug while writing the missing unit test.

The moral of this story is left as an exercise for the reader.

Fixes bug 1183884 harder.

Change-Id: I84b24dd930ba1bb6c4f674f8d3996639dedbce15
'}]
commit_message:
Better escaping for GET /v1/a?format=xml.

Commit 8f9b135 fixed a bug where an XML attribute could have arbitrary
characters jammed into it, resulting in a document with arbitrary
tags... and it did remove the ability to get an arbitrary XML document
out of the object server. However, it left a couple of ways to get a
malformed XML document, one example of which is an account named ".

This fixes up the remaining ways and ensures you always get a
well-formed XML document in the account-listing response. Also, it
adds a unit test for the escaping of the container name; this was
already working, just untested.

If you look in the discussion for bug 1183884, you'll see that the
review comments there are basically "seems good, but could use a unit
test". (The astute reader will note that I am one of the guilty
parties in that review.)

I found this bug while writing the missing unit test.

The moral of this story is left as an exercise for the reader.

Fixes bug 1183884 harder.

Change-Id: I84b24dd930ba1bb6c4f674f8d3996639dedbce15

revisions:
[{'created': '2013-06-14 14:05:56.000000000', 'message': 'Migrate to stevedore

Use stevedore to load both transport and storage drivers. It will allow
other users to extend Marconi with their own storages / transports more
easily. Stevedore also covers most of the cases around managing plugins.

Change-Id: Ic417c29cef41bdb72c8c446937905509db5ba8cd
'}]
commit_message:
Migrate to stevedore

Use stevedore to load both transport and storage drivers. It will allow
other users to extend Marconi with their own storages / transports more
easily. Stevedore also covers most of the cases around managing plugins.

Change-Id: Ic417c29cef41bdb72c8c446937905509db5ba8cd

[{'created': '2013-06-13 20:58:58.000000000', 'message': "Log retry attempts resulting from parallel message posts

This patch just adds a couple log entries, one when the first
attempt to post messages fails due to a race condition, and the
other when the post finally succeeds. Adding transaction IDs
will improve traceability, but that's another bp. :D

Change-Id: I188dae91f425e1effb6a12551e9d9f35c9549f71
Implements: blueprint bp/production-logging
"}]
commit_message:
Log retry attempts resulting from parallel message posts

This patch just adds a couple log entries, one when the first
attempt to post messages fails due to a race condition, and the
other when the post finally succeeds. Adding transaction IDs
will improve traceability, but that's another bp. :D

Change-Id: I188dae91f425e1effb6a12551e9d9f35c9549f71
Implements: blueprint bp/production-logging

commit_message:
pipeline: switch publisher loading model to driver

This change modify the loading of the publisher so it's driver based, like
our current storage model. That will allow to use the same publisher
multiple times with different parameters in the future.

This change also adds a new publisher called 'test' that comes from a
factorisation of some of the testing code.

Blueprint: pipeline-publisher-url

Change-Id: Ie26beac213383fff2db759e2df216ba1f454ef9c
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>
